summary: This is an email from an Assistant United States Attorney in the Southern District of New York, sent on November 28, 2021, regarding the upcoming trial of Ghislaine Maxwell. It is a motivational message to colleagues, asserting that it is never too late for justice and previewing that brave women will testify about Maxwell's sexual exploitation of underage girls. It provides logistical details for the trial's opening.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The accused in the criminal case 'United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell'. The email states she sexually exploited underage girls and caused harm to vulnerable kids.

persons.name: Assistant United States Attorney
persons.context: The author of the email, who is rallying colleagues from the Southern District of New York to support the opening of the Maxwell trial and expressing confidence in the case.

events.title: Opening of Ghislaine Maxwell Trial
events.description: The trial for United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell is scheduled to begin with peremptory challenges, preliminary instructions, and opening statements.

events.title: Reference to Historical Sex Crimes
events.description: The email references that some prosecutors would be afraid to charge a case requiring proof of sex crimes from 1994, contrasting with the SDNY's willingness to pursue the Maxwell case.

locations: One Saint Andrew's Plaza, New York, NY 10007
keyFacts: The document is a prosecutorial email rallying support for the opening of the Ghislaine Maxwell trial in the Southern District of New York.
It asserts the prosecution's core claim: 'Ghislaine Maxwell sexually exploited underage girls. She caused unspeakable harm to vulnerable kids.'
It contrasts the SDNY's approach with an implied criticism of prosecutors in Florida who might be reluctant to charge old cases, referencing sex crimes from 1994.
It provides specific logistical details for the trial's opening day, including multiple overflow courtrooms and a dedicated room for office staff.
The email frames the upcoming trial as a pursuit of justice where 'brave women will take the witness stand' and the truth will come out.
